  • A response that indicates that the value of X=1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahqart1ev3aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGybGaeyypa0 JaaGymaaaa@3B99@ has the greatest probability (i.e., X=1 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahqart1ev3aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGybGaeyypa0 JaaGymaaaa@3B99@ is most likely) is scored I.

  • A response that indicates the sum of the probabilities is 1 is scored I.

Solution

Part (d):

The random variable X MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahqart1ev3aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGybaaaa@39D8@ does not have a binomial distribution. While each trial has a binomial outcome (correct or incorrect) and there are a fixed number of trials (5), the probability of success does not remain the same for each trial and the trials are not independent.

Scoring

Part (d) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following two components:

Identifies that the distribution is not binomial

Indicates the lack of independence between trials or indicates the lack of constant probability for each trial

Partially correct (P) if the response states that X MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahqart1ev3aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGybaaaa@39D8@ does not have a binomial distribution and justifies with reference to each trial having more than two outcomes or reference to a non-fixed number of trials.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not satisfy the criteria for E or P.
Additional Notes:

  • A response that indicates lack of replacement may satisfy component 2. If the response subsequently links the lack of replacement to the non-constant probability and lack of independence, this can be considered if holistic scoring is required.

  • Including more than one reason that the distribution is not binomial should be considered if holistic scoring is required.

VR731745_rubric_category_0.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response

  • This question is scored in three sections. Each section is initially scored by determining if it meets the criteria for essentially correct (E), partially correct (P), or incorrect (I). The first section includes statements of the null and alternative hypotheses and identification of the appropriate hypothesis test. The second section includes verifying the conditions for the test identified in the first section and calculating the value of the test statistic and the corresponding p-value. The third section includes the conclusion for the test identified in the first section. The response is then categorized based on the scores assigned to each section and awarded an integer score between 0 and 4 (see the table at the end of the question).

  • The model solution represents an ideal response to each section of the question, and the scoring criteria identify the specific components of the model solution that are used to determine the score.

Scoring

Scoring sections 1, 2, and 3 are each scored as essentially correct (E), partially correct (P), or incorrect (I).

o.d:
All three sections incorrect

OR

One section partially correct and two sections incorrect
o.af:
Solution

Section 1:

The appropriate procedure is a chi-square goodness-of-fit test.

Let p i MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGWbWaaSbaaSqaaiaadMgaaeqaaaaa@3B0B@ represent the proportion of all drivers who use the airport’s parking who prefer to park in lot i. The null hypothesis to be tested is that the population proportions are as follows: p premium =0.150 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@456E@ , p general =0.295 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4558@ , p economy =0.370 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@456E@ , and p off-site =0.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4675@ if this question were to be asked of all drivers using airport parking.

The alternative hypothesis is that at least one of the population proportions of parking lot preferences stated in the null hypothesis is not correct if the question were asked of all drivers using airport parking.

Alternatively, H 0 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGibWaaSbaaSqaaiaabcdaaeqaaaaa@3AA6@ : the proportions of all drivers preferring to park in each lot is consistent with the proportions of spots available at the airport and H a MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGibWaaSbaaSqaaiaabggaaeqaaaaa@3AD7@ : the proportions of all drivers preferring to park in each lot is not consistent with the proportions of spots available at the airport.

Scoring

Section 1 is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following four components:

Identifies a chi-square goodness-of-fit test by name OR identifies a test statistic by a formula that includes a sum across four categories and that indicates the correct expected count for each category ( premium=51.45 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@443F@ , general=101.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4593@ , economy=126.91 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@44F8@ , and off-site=63.455 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@45A2@ )

States the correct null hypothesis

States the correct alternative hypothesis

Provides sufficient context by including references to:

  • Sampling units (parking lot users or drivers)

    AND

  • Population proportions (proportions for all drivers using airport parking lots)

    AND

  • The response variable (the response options to the question on parking lot preference)

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies three of the four components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.
Additional Notes:

  • Specifying a “chi-square test” is not sufficient to satisfy component 1. The response must indicate a chi-square goodness-of-fit test.

  • To satisfy component 1 with a formula, the formula must be of the form χ 2 = ( 63−51.45 ) 2 51.45 + ( 125−101.185 ) 2 101.185 + ( 111−126.91 ) 2 126.91 + ( 44−63.455 ) 2 63.455 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@79F7@ , i.e., it must indicate a sum. A response can use “…” as long as at least 2 of the terms are clearly shown with the correct expected count for each category.

  • If a response gives the formula χ 2 = ∑ ( obs−exp ) 2 exp MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4B6D@ and has clearly labeled observed and expected values anywhere on the page, component 1 is satisfied.

  • Component 1 is not satisfied if the response presents a test statistic formula that is inconsistent with a chi-square goodness-of-fit test, even if the response identifies a chi-square goodness-of-fit test in words.

  • Any discussion of the degrees of freedom for the test should be ignored in scoring.

  • The null hypothesis may be stated as H 0 : p p =0.15,  p g =0.295,  p e =0.37,  p o =0.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5BCA@ , or H 0 : p 1 =0.15,  p 2 =0.295,  p 3 =0.37,  p 4 =0.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5AFE@ , or H 0 : π p =0.15,  π g =0.295,  π e =0.37,  π o =0.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5EEA@ . Using subscripts P, G, E, and O, or clearly defined subscripts 1, 2, 3, and 4, the alternative hypothesis may be stated as H a : p p ≠0.15  or   p g ≠0.295  or   p e ≠0.37  or   p o ≠0.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7080@ , or as H a : π p ≠0.15  or   π g ≠0.295  or   π e ≠0.37  or   π o ≠0.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@73A0@ . The alternative hypothesis could be stated as “at least one of the proportions is not as stated in the null.”

  • An alternative hypothesis that states that each of the proportions is unequal to each of the proportions of parking spaces does not satisfy component 3, i.e., p p ≠0.15  and   p g ≠0.295  and   p e ≠0.37  and   p o ≠0.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7175@ .

  • Component 3 is not satisfied if the statement of the alternative hypothesis implies that no proportion is as stated in the null hypothesis, such as “The proportion of all drivers who would respond that they would park in each lot is not equal to the proportion of spaces in each lot.”

  • A response which states “the proportions of all drivers who would respond that they would park in each lot are not equal to the proportions of spaces in each lot” is equivalent to comparing distributions and satisfies component 3.

  • If a response clearly refers to the sample proportions instead of the population proportions using words or symbols (like p-hat) then component 4 is not satisfied unless the symbol used is defined as the population proportion. The response can still satisfy components 2 and 3 if the hypotheses are otherwise correct.

  • Component 4 is not satisfied if symbols other than p i MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGWbWaaSbaaSqaaiaadMgaaeqaaaaa@3B0B@ or π i MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacqaHapaCdaWgaaWcbaGaamyAaaqabaaaaa@3BD3@ are used and not clearly defined as the population proportion of users of the parking lots who would select the i − th MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3FDB@ response category.

  • If the response uses subscripts such as 1, 2, 3, 4, and the subscripts are not clearly identified as to which parking lot is assigned to which subscript then component 4 is not satisfied.

  • The elements of component 4 do not have to be satisfied with the statement of the hypotheses. They may be satisfied by work presented anywhere in the response, most likely by the statement of the conclusion.

  • The use of the term “distribution” may fulfill the proportion aspect of the second bullet of component 4, but not the population aspect.

  • A statement like H 0 : p p =0.15,  p g =0.295,... MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4DE6@ does not satisfy component 4. The parameters must be defined in order to satisfy component 4.

Solution

Section 2:

The conditions for using this test are satisfied:

  • The data were obtained from a random sample of drivers using the parking lots.

  • Because there are “tens of thousands” of drivers using the parking lots, the sample of 343 drivers using the parking lots is less than ten percent of the total number of drivers in the population.

  • All four expected counts, premium=51.45 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@443F@ , general=101.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4593@ , economy=126.91 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@44F8@ , and off-site=63.455 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@45A2@ are greater than 5.

The value of the test statistic is:

χ 2 = ( 63−51.45 ) 2 51.45 + ( 125−101.185 ) 2 101.185 + ( 111−126.91 ) 2 126.91 + ( 44−63.455 ) 2 63.455 ≈16.157. MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7E9B@

The p-value, determined from a chi-square distribution with 3 degrees of freedom, is approximately 0.0011 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D71@ .

Scoring

Section 2 is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following four components:

Correctly checks conditions for inference by including the following:

  • Noting that the data were obtained from a random sample

    AND

  • Noting that the sample of 343 drivers using the parking lots is less than ten percent of the total number of drivers

Justifying that the sample size is large enough by providing four correct expected values and noting that all are greater than a commonly accepted value such as 5 or 10

Correctly reports the value of the test statistic

Correctly reports the p-value

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only two or three of the four components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.

Additional Notes:

  • In order to satisfy the reference to the random selection of 343 drivers in component 1, it is minimally acceptable to state “random sample – check” or “SRS – check.” However, component 1 is not satisfied if the response implies that random assignment was used or only states “random – check.”

  • Component 2 is not satisfied if the response checks any inappropriate condition, such as “the sample size is at least 30.”

  • The response does not need to show the calculation of the values of the expected values to satisfy component 2 but must label them as expected values or write the values correctly in the test statistic formula.

  • Component 2 is not satisfied if the expected values are rounded to whole numbers, but components 3 and 4 can still be satisfied. If rounded to 51, 101, 127, and 64, the correct χ 2 =16.792 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4158@ with a p-value of 0.00078 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E38@ , or if rounded to 52, 101, 127, and 63, the correct χ 2 =15.776 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4159@ with a p-value of 0.0013 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D73@ satisfies components 3 and 4.

  • The response does not need to show any supporting work to satisfy either component 3 or component 4.

  • If the calculated value of the test statistic is either not reported or incorrect, component 3 may be satisfied if the response displays a correct formula for the test statistic with correct numerical values inserted for the observed and expected counts, e.g., χ 2 = ( 63−51.45 ) 2 51.45 + ( 125−101.185 ) 2 101.185 + ( 111−126.91 ) 2 126.91 + ( 44−63.455 ) 2 63.455 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@77C8@ .

  • A response that reports the correct value for the test statistic but contains errors in supporting work may still satisfy component 3.

  • If the calculated value of the test statistic is not reported, component 4 may be satisfied only by reporting the correct value for the p-value (based on the χ 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacqaHhpWydaahaaWcbeqaaiaaikdaaaaaaa@3B9C@ table, any value between 0.001 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaaIWaGaaiOlaiaaicdacaaIWaGaaGymaaaa@3C97@ and 0.0025 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D76@ may be accepted for the p-value).

  • Any discussion of the degrees of freedom for the test should be ignored in scoring section 2.

  • If the calculated value of the test statistic is incorrect, component 4 may be satisfied if the response provides the correct p-value for the reported value of the chi-square test, based on 3 degrees of freedom. The p-value may be checked with sufficient accuracy for scoring the response by referring to the following table of critical values for a chi-square test with 3 degrees of freedom.

  • If the response indicates an incorrect procedure involving proportions, section 2 of the response may be scored P if it correctly checks all conditions required for the application of the proposed method and reports a correct p-value for their procedure.

Solution

Section 3:

Because the p-value of 0.0011 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D71@ is less than α=0.05 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E86@ , the null hypothesis should be rejected. The data provide convincing statistical evidence that the proportion of all drivers preferring to park in each lot is not consistent with the proportion of spots available at the airport. That is, there is convincing statistical evidence that at least one of the proportions of all drivers preferring each lot is different from the proportion of spots available in each lot at the airport.

Section 3 is scored as follows:

Scoring

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following two components:

Provides correct comparison of the p-value to alpha (p-value is less than/greater than alpha) AND provides a correct decision about the null and/or alternative hypothesis

States a conclusion in context, consistent with, and in terms of, the alternative hypothesis using non-deterministic language

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only one of the two components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.
Additional Notes:

  • In order to satisfy component 1, the response must clearly identify the number that is compared to alpha as a p-value.

  • If the comparison and decision are consistent with an incorrect but reasonable p-value and correctly compares it to alpha (or an incorrect value of the test statistic, or an incorrect confidence interval), component 1 may be satisfied.

  • To satisfy the p-value comparison in component 1, the response can compare the value of the test statistic to an appropriate critical value, e.g., χ 2 >7.81 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3FDC@ .

  • The decision part of component 1 may be satisfied by implying the decision within the conclusion statement (sufficient evidence/insufficient evidence for the alternative hypothesis).

  • If an explicit decision is stated and the conclusion is inconsistent with the decision, component 1 is not satisfied.

  • To satisfy the context in component 2, the response must include the population parameter, sampling/experimental units, and the response variable.

  • If the response omits hypotheses, assume the correct alternative hypothesis is provided when scoring component 2.

  • If the response states incorrect hypotheses, component 2 may be satisfied by either stating a conclusion in terms of the stated alternative hypothesis or by answering the inference question.

  • Examples of non-deterministic language in component 2 include “evidence to accept the alternative,” “there is evidence for the alternative,” and “there is not sufficient evidence for the alternative.”

  • Examples of deterministic language in component 2 include “proves the null,” “proves the alternative,” “accepts the alternative,” “there is not evidence for the alternative,” and “no evidence for the alternative.”

  • If components 1 and/or 2 are satisfied and the response provides an incorrect interpretation of the p-value, the score is lowered from E to P or from P to I.

One section essentially correct and no section partially correct.

OR

No section essentially correct and two sections partially correct.

Solution

Section 2:

The conditions for using this test are satisfied:

  • The data were obtained from a random sample of drivers using the parking lots.

  • Because there are “tens of thousands” of drivers using the parking lots, the sample of 343 drivers using the parking lots is less than ten percent of the total number of drivers in the population.

  • All four expected counts, premium=51.45 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@443F@ , general=101.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4593@ , economy=126.91 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@44F8@ , and off-site=63.455 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@45A2@ are greater than 5.

The value of the test statistic is:

χ 2 = ( 63−51.45 ) 2 51.45 + ( 125−101.185 ) 2 101.185 + ( 111−126.91 ) 2 126.91 + ( 44−63.455 ) 2 63.455 ≈16.157. MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7E9B@

The p-value, determined from a chi-square distribution with 3 degrees of freedom, is approximately 0.0011 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D71@ .

Scoring

Section 2 is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following four components:

Correctly checks conditions for inference by including the following:

  • Noting that the data were obtained from a random sample

    AND

  • Noting that the sample of 343 drivers using the parking lots is less than ten percent of the total number of drivers

Justifying that the sample size is large enough by providing four correct expected values and noting that all are greater than a commonly accepted value such as 5 or 10

Correctly reports the value of the test statistic

Correctly reports the p-value

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only two or three of the four components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.

Additional Notes:

  • Component 2 is not satisfied if the expected values are rounded to whole numbers, but components 3 and 4 can still be satisfied. If rounded to 51, 101, 127, and 64, the correct χ 2 =16.792 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4158@ with a p-value of 0.00078 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E38@ , or if rounded to 52, 101, 127, and 63, the correct χ 2 =15.776 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4159@ with a p-value of 0.0013 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D73@ satisfies components 3 and 4.

Solution

Section 3:

Because the p-value of 0.0011 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D71@ is less than α=0.05 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E86@ , the null hypothesis should be rejected. The data provide convincing statistical evidence that the proportion of all drivers preferring to park in each lot is not consistent with the proportion of spots available at the airport. That is, there is convincing statistical evidence that at least one of the proportions of all drivers preferring each lot is different from the proportion of spots available in each lot at the airport.

Section 3 is scored as follows:

Scoring

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following two components:

Provides correct comparison of the p-value to alpha (p-value is less than/greater than alpha) AND provides a correct decision about the null and/or alternative hypothesis

States a conclusion in context, consistent with, and in terms of, the alternative hypothesis using non-deterministic language

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only one of the two components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.
Additional Notes:

  • In order to satisfy component 1, the response must clearly identify the number that is compared to alpha as a p-value.

  • If the comparison and decision are consistent with an incorrect but reasonable p-value and correctly compares it to alpha (or an incorrect value of the test statistic, or an incorrect confidence interval), component 1 may be satisfied.

  • To satisfy the p-value comparison in component 1, the response can compare the value of the test statistic to an appropriate critical value, e.g., χ 2 >7.81 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3FDC@ .

  • The decision part of component 1 may be satisfied by implying the decision within the conclusion statement (sufficient evidence/insufficient evidence for the alternative hypothesis).

  • If an explicit decision is stated and the conclusion is inconsistent with the decision, component 1 is not satisfied.

  • To satisfy the context in component 2, the response must include the population parameter, sampling/experimental units, and the response variable.

  • If the response omits hypotheses, assume the correct alternative hypothesis is provided when scoring component 2.

  • If the response states incorrect hypotheses, component 2 may be satisfied by either stating a conclusion in terms of the stated alternative hypothesis or by answering the inference question.

  • Examples of non-deterministic language in component 2 include “evidence to accept the alternative,” “there is evidence for the alternative,” and “there is not sufficient evidence for the alternative.”

  • Examples of deterministic language in component 2 include “proves the null,” “proves the alternative,” “accepts the alternative,” “there is not evidence for the alternative,” and “no evidence for the alternative.”

  • If components 1 and/or 2 are satisfied and the response provides an incorrect interpretation of the p-value, the score is lowered from E to P or from P to I.

  • If the response omits hypotheses, assume the correct alternative hypothesis is provided when scoring component 2.

  • Examples of deterministic language in component 2 include “proves the null,” “proves the alternative,” “accepts the alternative,” “there is not evidence for the alternative,” and “no evidence for the alternative.”

  • If components 1 and/or 2 are satisfied and the response provides an incorrect interpretation of the p-value, the score is lowered from E to P or from P to I.

Solution

Scoring

Section 1 is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following four components:

Identifies a chi-square goodness-of-fit test by name OR identifies a test statistic by a formula that includes a sum across four categories and that indicates the correct expected count for each category ( premium=51.45 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@443F@ , general=101.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4593@ , economy=126.91 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@44F8@ , and off-site=63.455 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@45A2@ )

States the correct null hypothesis

States the correct alternative hypothesis

Provides sufficient context by including references to:

  • Sampling units (parking lot users or drivers)

    AND

  • Population proportions (proportions for all drivers using airport parking lots)

    AND

  • The response variable (the response options to the question on parking lot preference)

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies three of the four components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.
Additional Notes:

  • Specifying a “chi-square test” is not sufficient to satisfy component 1. The response must indicate a chi-square goodness-of-fit test.

  • To satisfy component 1 with a formula, the formula must be of the form χ 2 = ( 63−51.45 ) 2 51.45 + ( 125−101.185 ) 2 101.185 + ( 111−126.91 ) 2 126.91 + ( 44−63.455 ) 2 63.455 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@79F7@ , i.e., it must indicate a sum. A response can use “…” as long as at least 2 of the terms are clearly shown with the correct expected count for each category.

  • If a response gives the formula χ 2 = ∑ ( obs−exp ) 2 exp MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4B6D@ and has clearly labeled observed and expected values anywhere on the page, component 1 is satisfied.

  • Component 1 is not satisfied if the response presents a test statistic formula that is inconsistent with a chi-square goodness-of-fit test, even if the response identifies a chi-square goodness-of-fit test in words.

  • Any discussion of the degrees of freedom for the test should be ignored in scoring.

  • The null hypothesis may be stated as H 0 : p p =0.15,  p g =0.295,  p e =0.37,  p o =0.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5BCA@ , or H 0 : p 1 =0.15,  p 2 =0.295,  p 3 =0.37,  p 4 =0.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5AFE@ , or H 0 : π p =0.15,  π g =0.295,  π e =0.37,  π o =0.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5EEA@ . Using subscripts P, G, E, and O, or clearly defined subscripts 1, 2, 3, and 4, the alternative hypothesis may be stated as H a : p p ≠0.15  or   p g ≠0.295  or   p e ≠0.37  or   p o ≠0.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7080@ , or as H a : π p ≠0.15  or   π g ≠0.295  or   π e ≠0.37  or   π o ≠0.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@73A0@ . The alternative hypothesis could be stated as “at least one of the proportions is not as stated in the null.”

  • An alternative hypothesis that states that each of the proportions is unequal to each of the proportions of parking spaces does not satisfy component 3, i.e., p p ≠0.15  and   p g ≠0.295  and   p e ≠0.37  and   p o ≠0.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7175@ .

  • Component 3 is not satisfied if the statement of the alternative hypothesis implies that no proportion is as stated in the null hypothesis, such as “The proportion of all drivers who would respond that they would park in each lot is not equal to the proportion of spaces in each lot.”

  • A response which states “the proportions of all drivers who would respond that they would park in each lot are not equal to the proportions of spaces in each lot” is equivalent to comparing distributions and satisfies component 3.

The response can still satisfy components 2 and 3 if the hypotheses are otherwise correct.

  • If the response uses subscripts such as 1, 2, 3, 4, and the subscripts are not clearly identified as to which parking lot is assigned to which subscript then component 4 is not satisfied.

  • The use of the term “distribution” may fulfill the proportion aspect of the second bullet of component 4, but not the population aspect.

Solution

Section 2:

The conditions for using this test are satisfied:

  • The data were obtained from a random sample of drivers using the parking lots.

  • Because there are “tens of thousands” of drivers using the parking lots, the sample of 343 drivers using the parking lots is less than ten percent of the total number of drivers in the population.

  • All four expected counts, premium=51.45 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@443F@ , general=101.185 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4593@ , economy=126.91 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@44F8@ , and off-site=63.455 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@45A2@ are greater than 5.

The value of the test statistic is:

χ 2 = ( 63−51.45 ) 2 51.45 + ( 125−101.185 ) 2 101.185 + ( 111−126.91 ) 2 126.91 + ( 44−63.455 ) 2 63.455 ≈16.157. MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7E9B@

The p-value, determined from a chi-square distribution with 3 degrees of freedom, is approximately 0.0011 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D71@ .

Scoring

Section 2 is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following four components:

Correctly checks conditions for inference by including the following:

  • Noting that the data were obtained from a random sample

    AND

  • Noting that the sample of 343 drivers using the parking lots is less than ten percent of the total number of drivers

Justifying that the sample size is large enough by providing four correct expected values and noting that all are greater than a commonly accepted value such as 5 or 10

Correctly reports the value of the test statistic

Correctly reports the p-value

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only two or three of the four components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.

Additional Notes:

  • In order to satisfy the reference to the random selection of 343 drivers in component 1, it is minimally acceptable to state “random sample – check” or “SRS – check.” However, component 1 is not satisfied if the response implies that random assignment was used or only states “random – check.”

  • Component 2 is not satisfied if the response checks any inappropriate condition, such as “the sample size is at least 30.”

  • The response does not need to show the calculation of the values of the expected values to satisfy component 2 but must label them as expected values or write the values correctly in the test statistic formula.

  • Component 2 is not satisfied if the expected values are rounded to whole numbers, but components 3 and 4 can still be satisfied. If rounded to 51, 101, 127, and 64, the correct χ 2 =16.792 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4158@ with a p-value of 0.00078 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E38@ , or if rounded to 52, 101, 127, and 63, the correct χ 2 =15.776 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4159@ with a p-value of 0.0013 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D73@ satisfies components 3 and 4.

  • If the calculated value of the test statistic is either not reported or incorrect, component 3 may be satisfied if the response displays a correct formula for the test statistic with correct numerical values inserted for the observed and expected counts, e.g., χ 2 = ( 63−51.45 ) 2 51.45 + ( 125−101.185 ) 2 101.185 + ( 111−126.91 ) 2 126.91 + ( 44−63.455 ) 2 63.455 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@77C8@ .

  • Any discussion of the degrees of freedom for the test should be ignored in scoring section 2.

  • If the calculated value of the test statistic is incorrect, component 4 may be satisfied if the response provides the correct p-value for the reported value of the chi-square test, based on 3 degrees of freedom. The p-value may be checked with sufficient accuracy for scoring the response by referring to the following table of critical values for a chi-square test with 3 degrees of freedom.

  • If the response indicates an incorrect procedure involving proportions, section 2 of the response may be scored P if it correctly checks all conditions required for the application of the proposed method and reports a correct p-value for their procedure.

Solution

Section 3:

Because the p-value of 0.0011 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D71@ is less than α=0.05 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E86@ , the null hypothesis should be rejected. The data provide convincing statistical evidence that the proportion of all drivers preferring to park in each lot is not consistent with the proportion of spots available at the airport. That is, there is convincing statistical evidence that at least one of the proportions of all drivers preferring each lot is different from the proportion of spots available in each lot at the airport.

Section 3 is scored as follows:

Scoring

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following two components:

Provides correct comparison of the p-value to alpha (p-value is less than/greater than alpha) AND provides a correct decision about the null and/or alternative hypothesis

States a conclusion in context, consistent with, and in terms of, the alternative hypothesis using non-deterministic language

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only one of the two components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.
Additional Notes:

  • In order to satisfy component 1, the response must clearly identify the number that is compared to alpha as a p-value.

  • If the comparison and decision are consistent with an incorrect but reasonable p-value and correctly compares it to alpha (or an incorrect value of the test statistic, or an incorrect confidence interval), component 1 may be satisfied.

  • To satisfy the p-value comparison in component 1, the response can compare the value of the test statistic to an appropriate critical value, e.g., χ 2 >7.81 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3FDC@ .

  • The decision part of component 1 may be satisfied by implying the decision within the conclusion statement (sufficient evidence/insufficient evidence for the alternative hypothesis).

  • If an explicit decision is stated and the conclusion is inconsistent with the decision, component 1 is not satisfied.

  • To satisfy the context in component 2, the response must include the population parameter, sampling/experimental units, and the response variable.

  • If the response omits hypotheses, assume the correct alternative hypothesis is provided when scoring component 2.

  • If the response states incorrect hypotheses, component 2 may be satisfied by either stating a conclusion in terms of the stated alternative hypothesis or by answering the inference question.

  • Examples of non-deterministic language in component 2 include “evidence to accept the alternative,” “there is evidence for the alternative,” and “there is not sufficient evidence for the alternative.”

  • Examples of deterministic language in component 2 include “proves the null,” “proves the alternative,” “accepts the alternative,” “there is not evidence for the alternative,” and “no evidence for the alternative.”

  • If components 1 and/or 2 are satisfied and the response provides an incorrect interpretation of the p-value, the score is lowered from E to P or from P to I.

The p-value, determined from a chi-square distribution with 3 degrees of freedom, is approximately 0.0011 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D71@ .

Scoring

Section 2 is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following four components:

Correctly checks conditions for inference by including the following:

  • Noting that the data were obtained from a random sample

    AND

  • Noting that the sample of 343 drivers using the parking lots is less than ten percent of the total number of drivers

Justifying that the sample size is large enough by providing four correct expected values and noting that all are greater than a commonly accepted value such as 5 or 10

Correctly reports the value of the test statistic

Correctly reports the p-value

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only two or three of the four components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.

Additional Notes:

  • In order to satisfy the reference to the random selection of 343 drivers in component 1, it is minimally acceptable to state “random sample – check” or “SRS – check.” However, component 1 is not satisfied if the response implies that random assignment was used or only states “random – check.”

  • Component 2 is not satisfied if the response checks any inappropriate condition, such as “the sample size is at least 30.”

  • The response does not need to show the calculation of the values of the expected values to satisfy component 2 but must label them as expected values or write the values correctly in the test statistic formula.

  • Component 2 is not satisfied if the expected values are rounded to whole numbers, but components 3 and 4 can still be satisfied. If rounded to 51, 101, 127, and 64, the correct χ 2 =16.792 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4158@ with a p-value of 0.00078 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E38@ , or if rounded to 52, 101, 127, and 63, the correct χ 2 =15.776 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4159@ with a p-value of 0.0013 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D73@ satisfies components 3 and 4.

  • The response does not need to show any supporting work to satisfy either component 3 or component 4.

  • If the calculated value of the test statistic is either not reported or incorrect, component 3 may be satisfied if the response displays a correct formula for the test statistic with correct numerical values inserted for the observed and expected counts, e.g., χ 2 = ( 63−51.45 ) 2 51.45 + ( 125−101.185 ) 2 101.185 + ( 111−126.91 ) 2 126.91 + ( 44−63.455 ) 2 63.455 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@77C8@ .

  • A response that reports the correct value for the test statistic but contains errors in supporting work may still satisfy component 3.

  • If the calculated value of the test statistic is not reported, component 4 may be satisfied only by reporting the correct value for the p-value (based on the χ 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacqaHhpWydaahaaWcbeqaaiaaikdaaaaaaa@3B9C@ table, any value between 0.001 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaaIWaGaaiOlaiaaicdacaaIWaGaaGymaaaa@3C97@ and 0.0025 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D76@ may be accepted for the p-value).

  • Any discussion of the degrees of freedom for the test should be ignored in scoring section 2.

  • If the calculated value of the test statistic is incorrect, component 4 may be satisfied if the response provides the correct p-value for the reported value of the chi-square test, based on 3 degrees of freedom. The p-value may be checked with sufficient accuracy for scoring the response by referring to the following table of critical values for a chi-square test with 3 degrees of freedom.

  • If the response indicates an incorrect procedure involving proportions, section 2 of the response may be scored P if it correctly checks all conditions required for the application of the proposed method and reports a correct p-value for their procedure.

Solution

Section 3:

Because the p-value of 0.0011 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3D71@ is less than α=0.05 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E86@ , the null hypothesis should be rejected. The data provide convincing statistical evidence that the proportion of all drivers preferring to park in each lot is not consistent with the proportion of spots available at the airport. That is, there is convincing statistical evidence that at least one of the proportions of all drivers preferring each lot is different from the proportion of spots available in each lot at the airport.

Section 3 is scored as follows:

Scoring

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following two components:

Provides correct comparison of the p-value to alpha (p-value is less than/greater than alpha) AND provides a correct decision about the null and/or alternative hypothesis

States a conclusion in context, consistent with, and in terms of, the alternative hypothesis using non-deterministic language

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only one of the two components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.
Additional Notes:

  • In order to satisfy component 1, the response must clearly identify the number that is compared to alpha as a p-value.

  • If the comparison and decision are consistent with an incorrect but reasonable p-value and correctly compares it to alpha (or an incorrect value of the test statistic, or an incorrect confidence interval), component 1 may be satisfied.

  • To satisfy the p-value comparison in component 1, the response can compare the value of the test statistic to an appropriate critical value, e.g., χ 2 >7.81 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3FDC@ .

  • The decision part of component 1 may be satisfied by implying the decision within the conclusion statement (sufficient evidence/insufficient evidence for the alternative hypothesis).

  • If an explicit decision is stated and the conclusion is inconsistent with the decision, component 1 is not satisfied.

  • To satisfy the context in component 2, the response must include the population parameter, sampling/experimental units, and the response variable.

  • If the response omits hypotheses, assume the correct alternative hypothesis is provided when scoring component 2.

  • If the response states incorrect hypotheses, component 2 may be satisfied by either stating a conclusion in terms of the stated alternative hypothesis or by answering the inference question.

  • Examples of non-deterministic language in component 2 include “evidence to accept the alternative,” “there is evidence for the alternative,” and “there is not sufficient evidence for the alternative.”

  • Examples of deterministic language in component 2 include “proves the null,” “proves the alternative,” “accepts the alternative,” “there is not evidence for the alternative,” and “no evidence for the alternative.”

  • If components 1 and/or 2 are satisfied and the response provides an incorrect interpretation of the p-value, the score is lowered from E to P or from P to I.

Provides the correct proportion for January with an approximate height of 0.52 (between 0.5 and 0.6) and December with an approximate height of 0.7, or consistent with the response from part (a)

Shows the width of the shaded area for January as approximately twice the width of the shaded area for December

Provides labels that are correct (i.e., the wider shaded area is identified as January and the other as December) and consistent with the legend

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only two of the three components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.
Additional Notes:

  • If the response does not use the entire width of the box provided, then component 2 can be satisfied provided the width of the bar for January is approximately twice the width of the bar for December.

  • If component 2 is not satisfied, then the labels provided should be consistent with the heights provided for each month in order to satisfy component 3.

  • Any graph other than a mosaic plot (or a bar graph) should be scored I. A bar graph with appropriate heights (component 1 is satisfied), bars of the same width (component 2 is not satisfied), and appropriate labels (component 3 is satisfied) should be scored P.

Solution

Part (c):

(i) The hypotheses for this test are H 0  : p j = p d H a  : p j < p d MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahqart1ev3aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakqaabeqaaiaabIeada WgaaWcbaGaaGimaaqabaGccaaMc8UaaiOoaiaadchadaWgaaWcbaGa amOAaaqabaGccqGH9aqpcaWGWbWaaSbaaSqaaiaadsgaaeqaaaGcba GaaeisamaaBaaaleaacaqGHbaabeaakiaaykW7caGG6aGaamiCamaa BaaaleaacaWGQbaabeaakiabgYda8iaadchadaWgaaWcbaGaamizaa qabaaaaaa@4B8F@

(ii) Because p=0.019<α=0.05, MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahqart1ev3aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaaqaaaaaaaaaWdbi aadchacqGH9aqpcaaIWaGaaiOlaiaaicdacaaIXaGaaGyoaiabgYda 8iabeg7aHjabg2da9iaaicdacaGGUaGaaGimaiaaiwdacaGGSaaaaa@45F7@ there is convincing statistical evidence that the true proportion of people 16 years and older from that city that were working or actively looking for work increased from January 2022 to December 2022.

Scoring

Part (c) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following three components:

States the correct equality for the null hypothesis for a difference in population proportions AND the correct direction for the one-sided alternative hypothesis for a difference in population proportions

Provides a correct comparison of the p-value to alpha (e.g., p-value is less than alpha) AND provides a correct decision about the null or alternative hypothesis

States a correct conclusion, in context, that is consistent with the direction, and in terms of, the stated alternative hypothesis OR states a conclusion, in context, that answers the inference question (e.g., states the conclusion in terms of Dr. Ogden’s belief)

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only two of the three components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not satisfy the criteria for E or P.

Additional Notes:

  • A response that correctly states the hypotheses in words (e.g., “the null hypothesis is that the proportions are equal, and the alternative hypothesis is that the January proportion is smaller than the December proportion”) satisfies component 1. Neither context nor the explicit reference to true or population is required to satisfy component 1.

  • A response that refers to the sample in the construction of the null and alternative hypotheses does not satisfy component 1.

  • A response can use a greater than or equal to in the construction of the null hypothesis.

  • The use of non-standard notation must be clearly defined to satisfy component 1 (e.g., p 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahqart1ev3aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGWbWaaSbaaS qaaiaaikdaaeqaaaaa@3AD8@ equals the true proportion of people 16 years and older from that city that were working or actively looking for work in December 2022).

  • If the response correctly computes the test statistic for a two-sample z-test for a difference between two population proportions  z  =2.08 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahqart1ev3aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaadaqadaqaamaaem aabaGaaGjcVlaadQhacaaMi8oacaGLhWUaayjcSdGaeyypa0JaaGOm aiaac6cacaaIWaGaaGioaaGaayjkaiaawMcaaaaa@45B7@ and correctly compares the test statistic against the rejection region  z  >1.645 , MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahqart1ev3aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaadaqadaqaamaaem aabaGaaGjcVlaadQhacaaMi8oacaGLhWUaayjcSdGaeyOpa4JaaGym aiaac6cacaaI2aGaaGinaiaaiwdaaiaawIcacaGLPaaacaGGSaaaaa@4729@ then the response satisfies the comparison part of component 2.

  • The decision in component 2 can be satisfied by either explicitly stating “reject H 0 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahqart1ev3aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGibWaaSbaaS qaaiaaicdaaeqaaaaa@3AAC@ ” OR implied in the conclusion from component 3.

  • In order to satisfy component 3, the conclusion must be consistent with the decision from component 2. If only a comparison of the p-value to alpha is provided in component 2, then the conclusion must be consistent with the comparison of the p-value to alpha. However, if neither a comparison nor a decision is provided in component 2, then the conclusion must be in context and consistent with the direction and in terms of the stated alternative hypothesis or states a conclusion, in context, that answers the inference question.

  • If the response omits the alternative hypothesis, assume the correct alternative hypothesis, H a : p j < p d , MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaahqart1ev3aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk 0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr 0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaqGibWaaSbaaS qaaiaabggaaeqaaOGaaiOoaiaadchadaWgaaWcbaGaamOAaaqabaGc cqGH8aapcaWGWbWaaSbaaSqaaiaadsgaaeqaaOGaaiilaaaa@417F@ was provided when scoring component 3.

Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response

  • Each part of the question (indicated by a letter) is initially scored by determining if it meets the criteria for essentially correct (E), partially correct (P), or incorrect (I). The response is then categorized based on the scores assigned to each letter part and awarded an integer score between 0 and 4.

  • The model solution represents an ideal response to each part of the question and the scoring criteria identify the specific components of the model solution that are used to determine the score.

Scoring

Parts (a), (b), (c), and (d) are each scored as essentially correct (E), partially correct (P), or incorrect (I).

Solution

Part (a):

The slope is positive which means that the correlation coefficient is also positive. Therefore, the correlation coefficient is r= 0.701 ≈0.837 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@441D@ value indicates a strong, positive association between young turtle age and length.

Scoring

Part (a) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following four components:

Correctly calculates the r MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGYbaaaa@39F3@ value

Describes the strength of the association (moderately strong or strong)

Describes the direction of the association (positive)

Includes context (association between young turtle age and length)

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only two or three of the four components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.
Additional Notes:

  • A response that shows only correct work or only the correct value 0.837 satisfies component 1.

  • If correct work is shown for component 1, an incorrect value between 0 and 1 satisfies component 1.

  • If an incorrect correlation coefficient is calculated in component 1, components 2 and/or 3 may be satisfied with an interpretation consistent with the incorrect value.

  • To satisfy component 4, it is minimally sufficient for the response to refer to the relationship between age and length without explicitly mentioning turtles.

Solution

Part (b):

(i)The female turtle has a negative residual, indicating the least-squares regression equation is over-predicting her length. The point corresponding to the 28-month-old female turtle is below the least-squares line.

(ii)The male turtle has a positive residual, indicating the least-squares regression equation is under-predicting his length by 3.13 cm. MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3F2D@

Scoring

Part (b) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following three components

Correctly identifies the female turtle as the point ( 28,40 ) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E2B@

Correctly interprets the residual

Includes context by referring to length

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only two of the three components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.
Additional Notes:

  • Component 2 may be satisfied by a response that does not directly mention the value 3.13.

  • Component 2 is not satisfied by a statement like “the difference between the observed and predicted length is 3.13 cm MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E7B@ " because it is not clear that the observed length is greater than the predicted length or that the predicted length is less than the observed length or that length has been under-predicted.

  • Component 2 is not satisfied by only a calculation (e.g., “ actual−predicted=3.13 cm MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4E49@ ”).

  • Component 2 is not satisfied if a student correctly interprets the residual but indicates that the turtle is female. However, component 3 may still be satisfied if the response refers to the length of the turtle.

  • To satisfy component 3, units are not required.

  • Component 3 is not satisfied if the residual is labeled with units of age (e.g., months or years).

Solution

Part (c):

(iii) The point-biserial coefficient is r pb = ( 42.78−35.88 ) 8 20 ( 1− 8 20 ) 4.79 ≈0.7057. MathType@MTEF@5@5@@589F@

(iv) Because the values of p and the standard deviation are the same for tortoises and turtles and the lengths of the male tortoises tend to be more similar to the lengths of female tortoises, the point-biserial correlation will be smaller because the numerator in the calculation is smaller. This would indicate the strength of the relationship between sex and length for the tortoises would be weaker than that of the turtles.

Scoring

Part (c) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following three components:

Correctly calculates r pb MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaacaWGYbWaaSbaaSqaaiaadchacaWGIbaabeaaaaa@3BFA@

Identifies that the tortoises would have a weaker relationship than the turtles

Justifies the relationship by referencing a smaller point-biserial correlation value

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only two of the three components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not satisfy the criteria for E or P.

Additional Notes:

  • A response that shows only values correctly substituted into the formula or only the correct value 0.7057 satisfies component 1.

  • If correct work is shown for component 1, an incorrect value between 0 and 1 satisfies component 1.

  • To satisfy component 3, a response may refer to any of the following:

    • the numerator will be smaller

    • the difference in mean lengths will be smaller

    • the value of the point-biserial correlation will be smaller

  • A response that indicates “stronger” cannot satisfy component 2 but may satisfy component 3 by stating that the point-biserial correlation will be larger (which is consistent with a stronger association).

Solution

Part (d):

Yes, age appears to be a confounding variable in the association between the length and sex of the turtles.

Based on the point-biserial correlation calculated in part (c-i), there is a moderately strong, positive association between the length and sex of the turtles.

Based on the original scatterplot, there appears to be a fairly strong, positive association between the age and length of the turtles.

The boxplots and summary statistics indicate a moderately strong association between the age and sex of the turtles. The boxplots show the median for male ages is higher (older) than about 75% of the females and the point-biserial correlation between sex and age is 0.50.

In this case, age would be a confounding variable because age is associated with the sex of the turtles and influences the length of the turtles. Therefore, it can’t be determined if the differences in the lengths of the turtles are due to their age or their sex, or a combination of both.

Scoring

Part (d) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following five components:

States that age appears to be a confounding variable in the association between the length and sex of the turtles

Indicates that there is an association between the length and sex of the turtles

Indicates that there is an association between the age and length of the turtles

Indicates that there is an association between the age and sex of the turtles

Justifies at least one of the associations from components 2-4 by referring to the appropriate graph or summary statistics (e.g., “based on the scatterplot,” or “in part (c)”)

Partially correct (P) if the explanation satisfies only four of the five components

OR

if the response satisfies component 5 and two other components

OR

if the response satisfies components 2, 3, and 4

OR

if the response gives a generic definition of confounding in the context of sex, age, and length.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not satisfy the criteria for E or P.

Additional Notes:

  • An example of a generic definition of confounding would include statements such as, “There is confounding because you can’t tell if it is age or sex that changes turtle length.”

Solution

Part (b):

Scoring

Part (b) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies four or five of the following five components:

Constructs the box beginning at Q1

Constructs the box ending at Q3

Locates the median within the box

Extends the lines on the boxplot to the minimum value

Extends the lines on the boxplot to the maximum value

Partially correct (P) if the response includes a boxplot with only three of the five components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.

Additional Notes:

  • A response that shows a graph or plot other than a boxplot should be scored incorrect (I).

  • To be correctly placed:

    • The minimum must be between the tick marks for 2 and 2.5

    • The first quartile must be between the tick marks for 4 and 4.5

    • The median must be between the tick marks for 5 and 5.5

    • The third quartile must be between the tick marks for 6 and 6.5

    • The maximum must be between the tick marks for 13 and 13.5

Part (b):

Scoring

Part (b) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies four or five of the following five components:

Constructs the box beginning at Q1

Constructs the box ending at Q3

Locates the median within the box

Extends the lines on the boxplot to the minimum value

Extends the lines on the boxplot to the maximum value

Partially correct (P) if the response includes a boxplot with only three of the five components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.

Additional Notes:

  • A response that shows a graph or plot other than a boxplot should be scored incorrect (I).

  • To be correctly placed:

    • The minimum must be between the tick marks for 2 and 2.5

    • The first quartile must be between the tick marks for 4 and 4.5

    • The median must be between the tick marks for 5 and 5.5

    • The third quartile must be between the tick marks for 6 and 6.5

    • The maximum must be between the tick marks for 13 and 13.5

Part (b):

Scoring

Part (b) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies four or five of the following five components:

Constructs the box beginning at Q1

Constructs the box ending at Q3

Locates the median within the box

Extends the lines on the boxplot to the minimum value

Extends the lines on the boxplot to the maximum value

Partially correct (P) if the response includes a boxplot with only three of the five components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.

Additional Notes:

  • A response that shows a graph or plot other than a boxplot should be scored incorrect (I).

  • To be correctly placed:

    • The minimum must be between the tick marks for 2 and 2.5

    • The first quartile must be between the tick marks for 4 and 4.5

    • The median must be between the tick marks for 5 and 5.5

    • The third quartile must be between the tick marks for 6 and 6.5

    • The maximum must be between the tick marks for 13 and 13.5

Part (b):

Scoring

Part (b) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies four or five of the following five components:

Constructs the box beginning at Q1

Constructs the box ending at Q3

Locates the median within the box

Extends the lines on the boxplot to the minimum value

Extends the lines on the boxplot to the maximum value

Partially correct (P) if the response includes a boxplot with only three of the five components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not meet the criteria for E or P.

Additional Notes:

  • A response that shows a graph or plot other than a boxplot should be scored incorrect (I).

  • To be correctly placed:

    • The minimum must be between the tick marks for 2 and 2.5

    • The first quartile must be between the tick marks for 4 and 4.5

    • The median must be between the tick marks for 5 and 5.5

    • The third quartile must be between the tick marks for 6 and 6.5

    • The maximum must be between the tick marks for 13 and 13.5

VR733934_rubric_category_0.ti: Part A, Part B, Part C
VR733934_rubric_category_0.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response

  • Each part of the question (indicated by a letter) is initially scored by determining if it meets the criteria for essentially correct (E), partially correct (P), or incorrect (I). The response is then categorized based on the scores assigned to each letter part and awarded an integer score between 0 and 4.

  • The model solution represents an ideal response to each part of the question, and the scoring criteria identify the specific components of the model solution that are used to determine the score.

Scoring

Parts (a), (b), and (c) are each scored as essentially correct (E), partially correct (P), or incorrect (I).

o.d:
All three parts incorrect

OR

One part partially correct and two parts incorrect
o.af:
Solution

Part (a):

Experimental units: 60 driveways.

Treatments: Concrete with fibers and concrete without fibers.

Response variable: Rating of the severity of the cracks after one year, on a scale of 0 to 10.

Scoring

Part (a) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following three components:

Identifies the experimental units as the driveways

Identifies the treatments as concrete with fibers and concrete without fibers

Identifies the response variable as the rating of the severity of the cracks

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only two of the three components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not satisfy the criteria for E or P.

Additional Notes:

  • The number of experimental units is not necessary to satisfy component 1.

  • The experimental units can be identified as “new homes needing driveways” to satisfy component 1.

  • The phrases “on a scale of 0 to 10” and “after one year” are not required for component 3.

  • Reasonable synonyms for “rating of the severity” such as “rating,” “severity,” or “on a scale of 0 to 10” are acceptable towards satisfying component 3.

  • Identification of the response variable as a mean, or average, does not satisfy component 3.

Solution

Part (b):

Number the 60 driveways from 01 to 60. Using a random number generator, generate two-digit integers between 01 and 60. Ignore 00 and any number greater than 60 until 30 unique numbers are obtained. Assign the driveways with those 30 unique numbers to receive concrete with fibers and the remaining 30 driveways to receive concrete without fibers.

Scoring

Part (b) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfied the following two components:

Describes how to correctly use a random number generator, or some other appropriate random process, to assign driveways that have been labeled 1 to 60 to concrete with fibers and concrete without fibers so that every possible random assignment is equally likely

The random process results in an equal number of driveways assigned to the concrete with fibers and the concrete without fibers
Partially correct (P) if the response describes how to implement a random process that satisfies only one of the two components.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not satisfy the criteria for E or P.

Additional Notes:

  • Examples of alternative random assignment processes that satisfy both component 1 and component 2 include:

    • Put 60 equally sized slips of paper labeled from 1 to 60 into a hat, mix well, and randomly select 30 slips of paper out of the hat, sampling without replacement. Assign the driveways with the numbers on the 30 selected slips of paper to concrete with fibers and assign the remaining 30 driveways to concrete without fibers.

    • Put 30 white marbles and 30 black marbles in an urn and mix well. Randomly select one marble from the urn. If the marble is white, assign the driveway with label 1 to concrete with fibers, otherwise assign the driveway with label 1 to concrete without fibers. Randomly select a marble from the remaining 59 marbles in the urn. If the marble is white, assign the driveway with label 2 to concrete with fibers, otherwise assign the driveway with label 2 to concrete without fibers. Continue this process of randomly selecting marbles from the urn without replacement until 30 driveways are assigned to concrete with fibers. The other 30 driveways are assigned to concrete without fibers.

    • Spin a spinner with 60 equally sized sections numbered from 1 to 60, ignoring repeats, until 30 unique numbers are generated. Assign the driveways with those 30 numbers to concrete with fibers and assign the remaining 30 driveways to concrete without fibers.

  • The following random assignment processes are examples that would satisfy component 2 but would not satisfy component 1.

    • An example that does not specify without replacement: Put 60 equally sized slips of paper labeled from 1 to 60 into a bowl, mix well, and randomly select one slip out of the bowl and record the number. Continue this process of randomly selecting slips until 30 numbers are recorded. Assign the driveways with the 30 recorded numbers to concrete with fibers and assign the remaining 30 driveways to concrete without fibers.

    • An example of a stopping rule with equal probabilities: Put 30 white marbles and 30 black marbles into an urn and mix well. Randomly select one marble from the urn. If the marble is white, assign the driveway with label 1 to concrete with fibers, otherwise assign the driveway with label 1 to concrete without fibers. Place the selected marble back into the urn, mix well, and randomly select a marble from the urn. If the marble is white, assign the driveway with label 2 to concrete with fibers, otherwise assign the driveway with label 2 to concrete without fibers. Continue this process of randomly selecting marbles from the urn with replacement until 30 driveways are assigned to concrete with fibers. The other 30 driveways are assigned to concrete without fibers.

    • An example where not all outcomes are equally likely: Toss 60 fair coins and record the number of heads. Continue tossing the 60 coins, and ignoring zero, until 30 unique numbers are recorded. Assign the driveways with the 30 recorded numbers to concrete with fibers and assign the remaining 30 driveways to concrete without fibers.

  • If there is not some type of labeling system (numbering the driveways), then component 1 is not satisfied.

  • If it is not clear that the random assignment process allows every possible random assignment of driveways to type of concrete to be equally likely, then component 1 is not satisfied.

  • If the response does not clearly indicate that random numbers are selected without using repeats, then component 1 is not satisfied.

  • A response that only assigns driveways to groups and does not indicate how the groups correspond to concrete with fibers and concrete without fibers does not satisfy component 1.

  • If a response describes two separate random assignment processes in detail (e.g., how to randomly assign number labels to driveways and how to randomly assign driveways to concrete type), score the combined random assignment process according to the two components.

  • If the response describes two ways to make the same random assignment (e.g., how to randomly assign driveways to treatments), assign the score for the weaker random assignment process.

Solution

Part (c):

The results were statistically significant, and because the driveways were randomly assigned to either the concrete with the fibers or the concrete without the fibers, there is evidence the treatment (type of concrete) caused the response (rating of severity of cracks).

Scoring

Part (c) is scored as follows:

Essentially correct (E) if the response satisfies the following two components:

The response indicates that random assignment enables the conclusion that type of concrete caused the rating of severity of the cracks

The explanation is in context of the problem

Partially correct (P) if the response satisfies only component 1,

OR

the response indicates random assignment limits the effect of confounding variables in context.

Incorrect (I) if the response does not satisfy the criteria for E or P.

Additional Notes:

  • If the response also indicates an incorrect conclusion based on random assignment, such as generalization, representation of the population, reduction of bias, or reduction of variability, reduce the score from an E to a P or from a P to an I.

  • Context includes either the treatment (concrete with fibers or concrete without fibers or “fibers”) or the severity rating.

One part essentially correct and no part partially correct.

OR

No part essentially correct and two parts partially correct.

Assign the driveways with the numbers on the 30 selected slips of paper to concrete with fibers and assign the remaining 30 driveways to concrete without fibers.

    • Put 30 white marbles and 30 black marbles in an urn and mix well. Randomly select one marble from the urn. If the marble is white, assign the driveway with label 1 to concrete with fibers, otherwise assign the driveway with label 1 to concrete without fibers. Randomly select a marble from the remaining 59 marbles in the urn. If the marble is white, assign the driveway with label 2 to concrete with fibers, otherwise assign the driveway with label 2 to concrete without fibers. Continue this process of randomly selecting marbles from the urn without replacement until 30 driveways are assigned to concrete with fibers. The other 30 driveways are assigned to concrete without fibers.

    • Spin a spinner with 60 equally sized sections numbered from 1 to 60, ignoring repeats, until 30 unique numbers are generated. Assign the driveways with those 30 numbers to concrete with fibers and assign the remaining 30 driveways to concrete without fibers.

  • The following random assignment processes are examples that would satisfy component 2 but would not satisfy component 1.

    • An example that does not specify without replacement: Put 60 equally sized slips of paper labeled from 1 to 60 into a bowl, mix well, and randomly select one slip out of the bowl and record the number. Continue this process of randomly selecting slips until 30 numbers are recorded. Assign the driveways with the 30 recorded numbers to concrete with fibers and assign the remaining 30 driveways to concrete without fibers.

    • An example of a stopping rule with equal probabilities: Put 30 white marbles and 30 black marbles into an urn and mix well. Randomly select one marble from the urn. If the marble is white, assign the driveway with label 1 to concrete with fibers, otherwise assign the driveway with label 1 to concrete without fibers. Place the selected marble back into the urn, mix well, and randomly select a marble from the urn. If the marble is white, assign the driveway with label 2 to concrete with fibers, otherwise assign the driveway with label 2 to concrete without fibers. Continue this process of randomly selecting marbles from the urn with replacement until 30 driveways are assigned to concrete with fibers. The other 30 driveways are assigned to concrete without fibers.

    • An example where not all outcomes are equally likely: Toss 60 fair coins and record the number of heads. Continue tossing the 60 coins, and ignoring zero, until 30 unique numbers are recorded. Assign the driveways with the 30 recorded numbers to concrete with fibers and assign the remaining 30 driveways to concrete without fibers.

  • If it is not clear that the random assignment process allows every possible random assignment of driveways to type of concrete to be equally likely, then component 1 is not satisfied.

Part (c):

The results were statistically significant, and because the driveways were randomly assigned to either the concrete with the fibers or the concrete without the fibers, there is evidence the treatment (type of concrete) caused the response (rating of severity of cracks).

The response indicates that random assignment enables the conclusion that type of concrete caused the rating of severity of the cracks

The explanation is in context of the problem

the response indicates random assignment limits the effect of confounding variables in context.
